title: The R package netseer
text: goal netseer predict graph structure including new nodes edges time series graphs. methodology explained preprint (Kandanaarachchi et al. 2025). illustrate example vignette.

title: The R package netseer
text: can install development version netseer GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("sevvandi/netseer")

title: The R package netseer
text: basic example shows predict graph next time point. First let us generate graphs. graphlist contains list graphs generated. graph igraph object. Let’s plot couple .
code: library(netseer) library(igraph) #>  #> Attaching package: 'igraph' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     decompose, spectrum #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     union  set.seed(2024) edge_increase_val <- new_nodes_val <- del_edge_val <- 0.1 graphlist <- list() graphlist[[1]] <- gr <-  igraph::sample_pa(5, directed = FALSE) for(i in 2:15){ gr <-  generate_graph_exp(gr,                           del_edge = del_edge_val,                           new_nodes = new_nodes_val,                           edge_increase = edge_increase_val ) graphlist[[i]] <- gr }

title: The R package netseer
code: plot(graphlist[[1]]) plot(graphlist[[8]]) plot(graphlist[[15]])

title: The R package netseer
text: Let’s predict next graph. argument h=1h = 1 specifies want predict graph next time point.
code: grpred <- predict_graph(graphlist[1:15],h = 1) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'tsibble': #>   method               from  #>   as_tibble.grouped_df dplyr #> Warning: 2 errors (1 unique) encountered for arima #> [2] missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod': #>   method            from #>   as.zoo.data.frame zoo grpred #> $graph_mean #> IGRAPH c28e147 U--- 34 23 --  #> + edges from c28e147: #>  [1]  1-- 2  1-- 4  1-- 5  1-- 6  1--14  1--25  2-- 3  2-- 4  2--21  3-- 6 #> [11]  3-- 9  3--17  3--29  5--10  5--12  9--20 10--11 11--19 11--20 17--19 #> [21] 28--29  1-- 3 17--34 #>  #> $graph_lower #> NULL #>  #> $graph_upper #> NULL  plot(grpred$graph_mean) ecount(grpred$graph_mean) #> [1] 23 vcount(grpred$graph_mean) #> [1] 34

what: Predicting the graph at 2 time steps ahead
title: The R package netseer
text: Now let us predict graph 2 time steps ahead h=2h=2.  see predicted graph h=2h=2 vertices edges graph h=1h=1.
code: grpred2 <- predict_graph(graphlist[1:15], h = 2) #> Warning: 2 errors (1 unique) encountered for arima #> [2] missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed grpred2 #> $graph_mean #> IGRAPH bb107df U--- 37 26 --  #> + edges from bb107df: #>  [1]  1-- 2  1-- 4  1-- 5  1-- 6  1--14  1--25  2-- 3  2-- 4  2--21  3-- 6 #> [11]  3-- 9  3--17  3--29  5--10  5--12  9--20 10--11 11--19 11--20 17--19 #> [21] 28--29  1-- 3  3-- 4  2-- 5  4-- 5 17--37 #>  #> $graph_lower #> NULL #>  #> $graph_upper #> NULL  plot(grpred2$graph_mean) ecount(grpred2$graph_mean) #> [1] 26 vcount(grpred2$graph_mean) #> [1] 37

what: Predicting the graph at 3 time steps ahead
title: The R package netseer
text: Similarly, can predict graph 3 time steps ahead. don’t limit hh. generally, get future, predictions less accurate. everything, just graphs.
code: grpred3 <- predict_graph(graphlist[1:15], h = 3) #> Warning: 2 errors (1 unique) encountered for arima #> [2] missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed grpred3 #> $graph_mean #> IGRAPH 8f44ef0 U--- 40 29 --  #> + edges from 8f44ef0: #>  [1]  1-- 2  1-- 4  1-- 5  1-- 6  1--14  1--25  2-- 3  2-- 4  2--21  3-- 6 #> [11]  3-- 9  3--17  3--29  5--10  5--12  9--20 10--11 11--19 11--20 17--19 #> [21] 28--29  1-- 3  3-- 4  2-- 5  4-- 6  5-- 6  2-- 9  1--10 17--40 #>  #> $graph_lower #> NULL #>  #> $graph_upper #> NULL  plot(grpred3$graph_mean) ecount(grpred3$graph_mean) #> [1] 29 vcount(grpred3$graph_mean) #> [1] 40

title: Authors and Citation
text: Sevvandi Kandanaarachchi. Author, maintainer. Stefan Westerlund. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kandanaarachchi S, Xu Z, Westerlund S, Sanderson C (2025). “Predicting Graph Structure via Adapted Flux Balance Analysis.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2507.05806. doi:10.48550/arXiv.2507.05806.
code: @Article{,   title = {Predicting Graph Structure via Adapted Flux Balance Analysis},   author = {Sevvandi Kandanaarachchi and Ziqi Xu and Stefan Westerlund and Conrad Sanderson},   journal = {arXiv preprint arXiv:2507.05806},   year = {2025},   doi = {10.48550/arXiv.2507.05806}, }

what: Graph Prediction from a Graph Time Series
title: Graph Prediction from a Graph Time Series
text: time series dynamic graphs changing structure, predict future graphs? goal netseer. Netseer predicts graph structure including new nodes edges time series graphs. adapts Flux Balance Analysis, method used metabolic network reconstruction predict structue future graphs. methodology explained preprint (Kandanaarachchi et al. 2025).

title: Graph Prediction from a Graph Time Series
text: algorithm available R Python. R package netseer CRAN can installed follows: vignette R package available [Get Started] https://sevvandi.github.io/netseer/
code: install_packages("netseer")

title: Graph Prediction from a Graph Time Series
text: Python package available PyPI https://pypi.org/project/netseer/. Python package can installed follows: documentation Python package available https://sevvandi.github.io/netseer-python/.
code: pip install netseer

title: Graph Prediction from a Graph Time Series
text: big shout Stefan Westerlund Brodie Oldfield contributions. Stefan optimized algorithm R coded scratch Python. Brodie packaged Python code website Python version.

what: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
title: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
text: Generates bigger graph using parameters node edge growth. sequence graphs created, number nodes sequence exponentially increase.

title: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
code: generate_graph_exp(   gr = NULL,   del_edge = 0.1,   new_nodes = 0.1,   edge_increase = 0.1 )

title: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
text: gr input graph generate next graph. set NULL graph using igraph::sample_pa used input graph. del_edge proportion edges deleted input graph. Default set 0.1. new_nodes proportion nodes added input graph. Default set 0.1. edge_increase proportion edges added input graph. Default set 0.1.

title: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
text: graph.

title: Generates a bigger graph using exponential growth. — generate_graph_exp
code: set.seed(1) gr <- generate_graph_exp() gr #> IGRAPH d5e9d4f U--- 6 4 -- Barabasi graph #> + attr: name (g/c), power (g/n), m (g/n), zero.appeal (g/n), algorithm #> | (g/c) #> + edges from d5e9d4f: #> [1] 1--2 1--3 1--4 2--5

what: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
title: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
text: Generates bigger graph using parameters node edge growth. sequence graphs created, number nodes linearly increase.

title: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
code: generate_graph_linear(   gr = NULL,   del_edge = 1,   new_nodes = 1,   edge_increase = 1,   edges_per_new_node = 3 )

title: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
text: gr input graph generate next graph. set NULL graph using igraph::sample_pa used input graph. del_edge number edges deleted input graph. Default set 1. new_nodes number nodes added input graph. Default set 1. edge_increase number edges added input graph. Default set 1. edges_per_new_node number edges added new nodes. Default set 3.

title: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
text: graph.

title: Generates a bigger graph by linear growth. — generate_graph_linear
code: set.seed(1) gr <- generate_graph_linear() gr #> IGRAPH f5d684a U--- 11 12 -- Barabasi graph #> + attr: name (g/c), power (g/n), m (g/n), zero.appeal (g/n), algorithm #> | (g/c) #> + edges from f5d684a: #>  [1] 1-- 2 1-- 4 1-- 7 1--11 2-- 3 2-- 5 2-- 6 5-- 6 5--11 6--10 7-- 8 8-- 9

what: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
title: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
text: function compares predicted graph actual comptues node edge error proportion

title: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
code: measure_error(actual, predicted)

title: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
text: actual ground truth actual graph. predicted predicted graph.

title: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
text: node error edge error proportion.

title: Gives an error measurement for predicted graphs — measure_error
code: data(syngraphs) # Taking the 20th graph as the actual and the 19th graph as predicted. measure_error(syngraphs[[20]], syngraphs[[19]]) #> $node_error #> [1] 0.08928571 #>  #> $edge_error #> [1] 0.1034483 #>

what: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
title: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
text: function predicts graph future time step using time series graphs.

title: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
code: predict_graph(   graphlist,   formulation = 2,   conf_level1 = NULL,   conf_level2 = 90,   dense_opt = 2,   weights_opt = 8,   weights_param = 0.001,   h = 1 )

title: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
text: graphlist list graphs igraph format. formulation Formulation 2 includes additional condition constraining total edges predicted value. Formulation 1 constraint. Formulation 2 gives realistic graphs due constraint. Default set 2. conf_level1 value 50 100 denoting confidence interval number predicted nodes graph. set NULL predicted graph mean number predicted nodes. set 80 example, 3 predicted graphs. One mean number predicted nodes, two number nodes corresponding lower upper confidence bounds. conf_level2 upper confidence bound degree distribution. Default set 90. dense_opt set 2 dense option R package lpSolve used. weights_opt Weights option ranging 1 6 used different edge weight schemes. Weights option 1 uses uniform weights edges. Option 2 uses binary weights. edge existed past graph, weight set 1. Else set 0. possible new edges assigned weight 1. Option 3 selective version. Option 4 uses proportional weights according history. Option 5 uses proportional weights, network past, gives less weight. Option 5 uses linearly decaying proportional weights. Option 6 uses harmonically decaying weights. network T given weight 1,  T-1 given weight 1/2 . Option 7 uses 1 edges present last graph. Option 8 slightly different Option 7. uses 1 edges last seen graph weights_param new edges. Default set 8. weights_param weight given possible edges new vertices. Default set 0.001. h prediction time step. Default  h = 1.

title: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
text: list predicted graphs. conf_level1 NULL, 3 graphs returned one mean number predicted nodes 2 number nodes equal lower upper bound values prediction. conf_level1 NULL, mean predicted graph returned.

title: Predicts a graph from a time series of graphs. — predict_graph
code: set.seed(2024) edge_increase_val <- new_nodes_val <- del_edge_val <- 0.1 graphlist <- list() graphlist[[1]] <- gr <-  igraph::sample_pa(5, directed = FALSE) for(i in 2:15){   gr <-  generate_graph_exp(gr,                         del_edge = del_edge_val,                         new_nodes = new_nodes_val,                         edge_increase = edge_increase_val )   graphlist[[i]] <- gr } grpred <- predict_graph(graphlist[1:15], conf_level2 = 90, weights_opt = 6) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'tsibble': #>   method               from  #>   as_tibble.grouped_df dplyr #> Warning: 2 errors (1 unique) encountered for arima #> [2] missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod': #>   method            from #>   as.zoo.data.frame zoo  grpred #> $graph_mean #> IGRAPH e138ec9 U--- 34 23 --  #> + edges from e138ec9: #>  [1] 28--29 17--19 11--20 11--19 10--11  9--20  5--12  5--10  3--29  3--17 #> [11]  3-- 9  3-- 6  3-- 5  2--21  2--17  2-- 4  2-- 3  1--25  1--14  1-- 6 #> [21]  1-- 5  1-- 4  1-- 2 #>  #> $graph_lower #> NULL #>  #> $graph_upper #> NULL #>
